CLIST.TITLE: Patents
CLIST.ITEM:
United States Patent and Trademark Officehttps://www.uspto.gov/
enHTML (searchhttps://ppubs.uspto.gov/pubwebapp/static/pages/landing.html
enHTML)

X.T: Computing machinery and intelligence - A. M. Turing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Probably the most well-known computer article: Turing is defining his imitation test.
TimHowes presents what is and what is not LDAP, he summarises its history and gives examples of its current use.

This could have been the usual Wired vision (a kind of technological/financial optimism) but ChristopherDickey is not usually writing for the magazine, so the description of French start-up’s is less enthusiastic than expected.

X.T: Welcome to Sealand. Now Bugger Off.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: When cyberpunk SF becomes true: some cypherpunks try to create an offshore/offjurisdiction data haven on a WWII antiaircraft platform.
What happens to the code when a company dies… Most of the times, it is lost, but not always: the example of Dragon’s NaturallySpeaking.
A presentation of MisterHouse, a software to automate home devices. Take care to bugs in your scripts…
Using metaphor with other human activities can be useful to formulate questions, but is dangerous when used to justify answers.

X.T: Is your laptop a pain in the neck?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Muscular-skeletal disorders are more frequent with laptops.
The idea to interrogate some well-known programmers if programming as an art is good, but the result is slightly disappointing.
The author describes the problems with community documentation and a possible rating system. I don’t feel this one is realistic…
The problem of some words losing their real meaning when they are in fashion.

X.T: Using Google to View MySpace or Any Restricted Site

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some well-known tricks to bypass simple Web filters.

X.ST: Community topics pave the way for a new twist on developer collaboration

ARTICLE.COMMENT: IBM is updating its developer site to Web 2.0.

X.T: Microsoft unveils touch screen computing - Giant computer blends reality with virtual reality

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A demo of Microsoft tabletop touch computer.
GeorgeDyson tells a history of Von Neumann’s computer work full of anecdotes.

X.T: Beyond mobile broadband, WiMAX is about blowing up the wireless business model

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Why WiMax is more than just a new wireless standard.

X.T: ShapeWriter: making gesture writing on mobile devices easy, fast, and fun

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of ShapeWriter, a software to recognise words of a soft keyboard, with some impressive demos.
The title says it all.

X.T: Lone Star Ruby Conference 2010 Real Software Engineering by Glenn Vanderburg

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Software engineering is different of the other engineering domains, software engineering must be defined by the practitioners, source code is a model…

X.T: Software Art Thou: Glenn Vanderburg - Real Software Engineering

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The same presentation several years later.

X.ST: The Computer History Simulation Project and SIMH

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of SIMH, a multi-system emulator.

X.T: Where Did This Code Come From? Discovering the Provenance of Program Binaries

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using statistical machine learning to infer the language, compiler, author… of some binary code.

X.T: Meet the tireless entrepreneur who squatted at AOL

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Eating, sleeping, practicing sport, showering in AOL building while trying to launch a startup.

X.T: Shyam Sankar: The rise of human-computer cooperation

ARTICLE.COMMENT: While I agree with the idea that intelligently using a simple software is more productive that trying to implement and blindly use a more complex algorithm, this presentation smells as bullshit with many samples seeming a biased description of simple computer usage.

X.T: Robert C. Martin - Professional Software Development

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Short iterations, never be blocked (because waiting for someone else), screaming architectures (architectures should express the domain, not the technologies they use), incremental improvements (instead of the big rewrite), TDD, saying "no".

X.T: Txt2tags: A great lightweight markup language for many tasks

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very short presentation of Txt2tags.

X.T: Erik Meijer: Latency, Native Relativity and Energy-Efficient Programming

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some thoughts about extending the usual time vs. space duality by considering latency and energy.
The advantages and the problems with programs that support being customised from the inside.
The end of Unix 32 bits epoch.
Picking a language, Scala, in order to attract developers to work in your company.
Some advice for solving a problem: read the error message, google the error message, ask a peer, ask an expert, record the resolution.

X.T: Tim Ewald - Clojure: Programming with Hand Tools

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The tools you use change the way you see the world, see Maslow’s hammer.

X.ST: Adventures in Unicode, Real-time Streaming, and Media Culture

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A long description of how Emojitracker has been built.
Perfect agile teams are very rare. The open-source model, with a small core of "foremen" reviewing patches of all the contributors, is seen much more often and proved to be effective.
Some high-level ideas about morphogenesis: TBD automates, Turing machines, cellular automata, L-systems… But there is no details about implementing a morphogenesis algorithm.
Forcing oneself to write code every day.

X.T: Yes, you can speak at a conference

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author advices to give talks at conferences, this is a good way to learn, and he gives some counsel to prepare these talks.
Building tools to get more frequent and more comprehensive feedback.
Some stories of the past time in TekLabs and some comments about today.

X.T: Why good developers write bad code: an observational case study of the impacts of organizational factors on software quality

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A study of the problems met by a development team: there is nothing surprising here, but the description of these problems is clear.
RobertCecilMartinUncle Bob explains his hypothesis why men have replaced women in computing: this occurred when people realised that programming means power.
The history of Apple I.

X.T: It's All Good: The False Dichotomy Between Planned and Improvisational Projects

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Planned projects and agile ones are not contradictory, both are better than the other ones in some situations.
Kent’s process for promoting an idea.

X.T: In The Beginning: The Birth Story in Idea to Impact

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A complement of the previous blog: the totem of an idea can be the story of its birth.
The vicious circle of using kludges to limit code change and risk, and having these kludges making the code even riskier to change.

X.T: How to Build a High Velocity Development Team
X.ST: Be the Quantum Leap

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some common ideas expressed with strong words and little facts.
Bullshit around XP’s sustainable pace of 40 hours per week.

X.T: Developing Like There's No Tomorrow • Frank Lyaruu • GOTO 2015

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of Sendrato’s wristband used for tracking participants to an event.
The first part describes some old mechanism to generate pieces of art. The second part is a fuzzy description of implementing analogy mechanisms.
A good analysis of the advantages/disadvantages of co-located vs. remote teams.

X.T: John Carmack’s Deep Thoughts: Ideas, Work, and Emotion

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some interesting thought about ideas.

X.ST: By Betable CTO, Mike Malone

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good description of the problem with V8’s Math.random() implementation.
The title says it all.

X.T: Lean Startup: la méthode qui plante 93 start-up sur 100

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some basic advice dismantling some fads popular among startups.

X.T: Code Golf & the Bitshift Variations - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Explaining a C code-golf generating music.

X.T: Facebook Hired Me At 18. But My Story Isn’t As Perfect As It Sounds.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: MichaelSayman, the "successful kid who built apps and inspires others", explains that his life was much less happy than it seemed.

X.T: Shorter Feedback is not Always Bett

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Having a shorter feedback loop does not help if the Controller / System / Sensor system is not stable…
Experimenting with a training format mixing short videos and chat.

X.ST: How the image of software developers came about

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How the situation changed from the initial women working on the ENIAC to the current software world which is strongly dominated by males.

X.T: How Big Data Creates False Confidence

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Numbers extracted from big data should be interpreted with care instead of being blindly trusted.
Real time dashboards are a source of disturbance and are not helpful to solve the real problems.
Kent starts explaining his model of product development: Explore / Expand / Extract.

X.T: A Good Craftsman Never Blames His Tools

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to handle the fact that you join, as a consultant, a team that is using tools that you would like to change.

X.T: Carina Zona - Consequences of an Insightful Algorithm

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A long list of bad side effects of data mining and some advice on being responsible when using deep learning.
Reed-Muller code and building it using Hadamard matrices.

X.T: Reed-Muller Code (64 Shades of Grey pt2) - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The continuation of the previous video.

X.T: Developers Who Use Spaces Make More Money Than Those Who Use Tabs
X.ST: Do you use tabs or spaces for code indentation?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: StackOverflow data shows that salary is positively correlated to using spaces for indentation.
A high-level description of OCR algorithms.

X.T: Lessons from my first year of live coding on Twitch

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: 5 Step Recipe: Everything You Need to Know for Staying Up-to-Date in Java

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Why Computers are Bad at Algebra | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A basic and clear explanation of IEEE 754.

X.T: 10 Tips on How to be a Great Programmer

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: VW engineer sent to the clink for three years for emissions-busting code
X.ST: James Liang gets 40 months on the cooler and $200,000 fine

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A first minor executive is sentenced.
Trying to draw a 2D map of the different domains of computer science.

X.ST: A small group of programmers wants to change how we code—before catastrophe strikes.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A non-technical presentation of some ideas to change the way software is built: BretVictor’s Light Table, EricBantégnie’s Esterel, LeslieLamport’s TLA+.
A comment on the previous article: the solution is not more tools, but better programming discipline.
About the few who condemn political incorrectness by using dishonourable means.
A rational against hiring quotas.

X.T: The Biggest Software Mistake That Small Business Owners Make

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This article states the obvious: having a single developer is a bad situation.
The end of Moore’s Law means that the software industry will have reach adulthood and get more professional.
The history of data storage and its impact on software design.
An analogy with flying a plane, but the message is always the same: trying to go fast without taking care of the quality will slow you down.

X.T: Master Data Management définition : gestion des données de référence

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short overview of what is Master Data Management.
The problem of being able to read files or execute programs several years after their creation.
KentBeck uses an analogy with poker to explain that, in large companies where projects take more time, developers work on less projects and chose the ones with less risk.
DDD is an offensive term because it is a bra size.
8th Light staff is listing the technologies which are gaining popularity.
A presentation of MartinGardner’s Hexapawn.

X.T: Yes, You Can Write an Awesome Game in Just 10 Lines of Basic
X.ST: An annual contest challenges programmers to create 8-bit games of intrigue and adventure

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A competition of games written with 10 lines of Basic.
Some marketing for RPA, Acial, and its use of UiPath.
An explanation of the undecidability of the halting problem using Python.

X.T: How (some) good corporate engineering blogs are written

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Comparing the publication process for companies with good and bad blogs.
A description of the EPUB format.

X.T: How Traceroute Works (Building a Movie Scene 'Trace' Map) - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: 10 MILLION Characters On Screen?! - Ultimate Epic Battle Simulator 2 The Making Of Pt1

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An impressive demo of an uninteresting game: Ultimate Epic Battle Simulator 2.

X.T: The lives of two Stanford-students-turned-founders reveal tech’s misplaced priorities
X.ST: Joshua Browder and Aaron Swartz were both technologists who attended the prestigious Silicon Valley school. But history treats them very differently.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: AaronSwartz has been forgotten, today’s Stanford University students only know about the successful startuppers without conscience.

X.T: German Court Rules Websites Embedding Google Fonts Violates GDPR

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A fine for transmitting IP addresses, which are personal data, to Google.

X.T: Time-shifted computing could slash data center energy costs by up to 30%
X.ST: Proof-of-concept paper shows how data centers could help manage the grid.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Saving money by performing some computation in advance when electricity is cheaper.
A simple description of a 1988 article "Congestion avoidance and control".

X.T: EU announces Big Tech crackdown, demands interoperability between platforms
X.ST: Lawmakers agree on Digital Markets Act to regulate Big Tech; final votes still pending.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Can you find: five five-letter words with twenty-five unique letters?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: MattParker wrote a bad algorithm to find five five-letters words having no common letter.

X.T: Deleted scene: five words with twenty-five letters

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A detail about his algorithm.
The story became a collective race to build the fastest algorithm.
Microsoft has open-sourced its Emoji library.
A much too basic introduction of knowledge graphs.

X.T: Cloudflare’s CAPTCHA replacement lacks crosswalks, checkboxes, Google
X.ST: Cloud giant says its verification tool doesn't challenge or profile users.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Cloudflare wants to replace Google’s reCAPTCHA with its Turnstile.
A high-level presentation of HTTP/3.
If AI becomes able to help configuring the deployment of applications instead of the current situation where users must know about much too many primitives, this would be the next major change.

X.T: Ces entreprises en lice dans la bataille du cloud de confiance

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The current companies trying top build a French Cloud of Trust.
A comparison of how different visualisations are perceived.

X.T: Talk Six Impossible Things by Kevlin Henney

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A funny keynote about well-known memes: infinity, undecidability, future cannot be predicted…

X.T: TLA+ Helps Programmers Squash Bugs Before Coding
X.ST: The language from LaTeX’s inventor is already used by Amazon, Microsoft, and Oracle

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short non-technical presentation of TLA+.

X.T: Are These Software Myths True or False? • Dave Farley • GOTO 2023

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It is a good idea to refer to scientific studies to differentiate urban legends and facts, but these studies are doubtful.
A (slow) description of counter machines and an explanation why they are equivalent to Turing machines.

X.T: EXTRA BITS - More on Counter Machines - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The continuation of the previous video: a counting machine with any number of counters can be replaced by a machine with two counters.

X.T: In Depth BDD & Contributing To Cucumber | Seb Rose In The Engineering Room Ep. 22

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good discussion about various subject: writing tests at the right abstraction level, coaching, microservices…

X.T: Developers Blamed For The Post Office Horizon Scandal?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The shameful behaviour of Fujitsu and the UK Post Office which refused to admit that the software was buggy and some technical information about the defaults.

X.T: How to get in the flow while coding (and why it’s important)
X.ST: Explore what flow state entails, its benefits, and three tips for reaching it the next time you code.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another presentation of the flow state, with a bunch of memes, some being bullshit.

X.T: Software-defined vehicles: The future of the automotive industry?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information about SDV.

X.T: Design Patterns that Encourage Junk Data

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Asking companies to think about ways to encourage their users to delete obsolete unuseful data.

X.T: The Most Important Programming Invention In 20 Years

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Git, Cloud, Docker, LLM. I would rather disagree, as DaveFarley also does.

X.T: Qu'est ce que les champignons nous apprennent sur l'intelligence artificielle? (Marine SOBAS)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: MarineSobas does not master what she is talking about. For example, physarum polycephalum is not a fungus.
Green bullshit.

X.T: La loi de Moore est morte et c'est une bonne nouvelle

ARTICLE.COMMENT: I cannot believe some persons really believe in such a message. Companies have no incentive to reduce the electricity bill, they prefer to add new features, just look at the current AI craziness.

X.T: SDS 817: The Positron IDE, Tidy NLP and MLOps with Dr. Julia Silge
817: The Positron IDE, Tidy NLP and MLOps — with Dr. @JuliaSilge

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information about Positron, an IDE for data scientist, Vetiver, a framework to version and deploy models, and Tidyverse, a collection of R packages.

X.T: Build Your Own Radar: Using the Technology Radar as a governance tool

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Thoughworks explains why they created their technology radar, how they help their customers create their own one, and the fact that the open-sourced it.
A presentation of the theme of the future radar update: AI code assistance antipatterns, Rust, WebAssembly, and the explosion of generative AI tools.

X.T: Oxide and Friends 12/16/2024 -- Scaling Bluesky with Paul Frazee

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The description of some technical aspects of Bluesky.
Some predictions for the next year, three years, and six years.

X.T: My AI/LLM predictions for the next 1, 3 and 6 years, for Oxide and Friends

ARTICLE.COMMENT: SimonWillison presents the predictions; for which he has no confidence, he did in the previous podcast.
A basic presentation of digital twins.

X.T: A computer can never be held accountable

ARTICLE.COMMENT: From an IBM training in 1979: "A computer can never be held accountable - Therefore a computer must never make a management decision".
Supervised agents in coding assistants, evolving observability, R in RAG, and taming the data frontier.

X.ST: What I Learned Working at Google

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some characteristics of complex systems and some ways to manage them.

X.T: Why the tech industry needs "Expert Generalists"

ARTICLE.COMMENT: UnmeshJoshi and MartinFowler explain that people can learn to be good generalists by mastering first principle and being collaborative to get the team’s job done.
A high-level introduction to gradual typing, a language feature allowing parts of a program to be dynamically typed and other parts to be statically typed.
A history of the type systems in computer languages.

X.T: These Angry Dutch Farmers Really Hate Microsoft
X.ST: Tech giants want to build massive, “hyperscale” data centers in the Netherlands. A popular political movement wants them stopped.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Netherlands defined some rules to limit nitrogen pollution, but Microsoft is able to continue to build its data centre.

X.T: L’idée de génie de ce DATACENTER 💡

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The visit of the newest and the previous Infomaniak data centres.

X.T: Power-hungry AI is putting the hurt on global electricity supply
X.ST: Data centers are becoming a bottleneck for AI development.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all. AI is becoming a huge electricity consumer. Maybe electricity should be more expensive, so the models would not be so cheap, and people would think twice before using them.

X.T: Taking a closer look at AI’s supposed energy apocalypse
X.ST: AI is just one small part of data centers’ soaring energy use.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A debunk of recent articles about AI energy consumption surge.

X.T: Amazon Vies for Nuclear-Powered Data Center
X.ST: The deal has become a flash point over energy fairness

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some data centres are connected directly to nuclear plants, which means that the do not have to pay fees to maintain the grid.

Some unusual ideas to make you think: kill agile, Scrum is talking about code instead of coding, a company should have a closed feedback loop to react to its environment, push in production instead of doing TDD…
Commenting the previous video.

X.T: The Responsive Enterprise: Embracing the Hacker Way
X.ST: Soon every company will be a software company.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Software is omnipresent, companies must work in closed-loop mode, effective organisations are hierarchical, developers must be well paid and handle the tactics while senior leaders handle the strategy…

X.ST: License Information on GIF and Other LZW-based Technologies

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The real legal status of the LZW patent: it will be expired July 7, 2004 in the last country (Canada).
This is the report of a phone call between TimO’Reilly and JeffBezos: they have spoken about the patent issue.

X.ST: Le 25 mai 2018, le règlement européen est entré en application. De nombreuses formalités auprès de la CNIL disparaîssent. En contrepartie, la responsabilité des organismes est renforcée. Ils doivent désormais assurer une protection optimale des données à chaque instant et être en mesure de la démontrer en documentant leur conformité.

X.T: Règlement européen sur la protection des données personnelles se préparer en 6 étapes
X.ST: En mai 2018, le règlement européen sera applicable. De nombreuses formalités auprès de la CNIL vont disparaître. En contrepartie, la responsabilité des organismes sera renforcée. Ils devront en effet assurer une protection optimale des données à chaque instant et être en mesure de la démontrer en documentant leur conformité.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A process to comply with the GDPR.

X.T: 'Leap Second' Bug Wreaks Havoc Across Web
X.ST: Reddit, Mozilla, and several other big name web outfits experienced brief technical problems on Saturday evening, when software unpinning their online operations choked on the "leap second" that was added to the world's atomic clocks.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Amazon, LinkedIn, Foursquare… failed to manage the leap second, Google was prepared and had no problem.

X.T: Leap seconds could become leap minutes, despite pushback from Russians, Vatican
X.ST: Already endangered, the leap second might have a practical successor soon.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Oxide and Friends 12/9/2024 -- Conferences in Tech

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Memories of technical conference veterans.

X.T: Oxide and Friends 5/12/2025 -- RIP USENIX ATC

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some miscellaneous ideas about conferences in the past and the fact that attendees were no more practitioners but academics.
